Situation1: They are approached by someone struggling with personal or family issues and need to provide consistent guidance and encouragement.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I was just about to leave the church office for my volunteer shift at the food pantry when Mrs. Kim knocked on my door, her eyes red and voice trembling. She needed to talk—her son was in trouble again, and she didn’t know where else to turn. As her pastor, I knew how much she counted on me for comfort and guidance, especially in moments like this. But I glanced at the clock and realized I was already cutting it close for my shift. The pantry coordinator always emphasized punctuality, and I’d promised to set a good example. Still, I also knew the other volunteers could handle things for a while if I was late. My heart ached as I listened to Mrs. Kim pour out her worries, feeling the weight of her trust in me. At the same time, guilt gnawed at me for possibly letting down my fellow volunteers. I stood there, torn, the expectations of both roles pressing in on me, unsure which responsibility should come first.
